Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Expectation2: Diagnose patient illnesses accurately based on symptoms and tests
Situation2: A patient has a combination of unusual symptoms that are not immediately linked to a single known illness.
Story:
I was just finishing up my shift at the clinic when I ran into Mark in the parking lot. We’d met a few times at community events, so when he waved me over, I smiled and walked his way. “Hey, do you know any good restaurants around here?” he asked, rubbing his stomach. “I’ve been feeling off lately, but I’m starving and want to try something new.”

As his acquaintance, I wanted to be friendly and helpful, maybe suggest the Italian place down the street. But as a doctor, I couldn’t ignore the way he looked—pale, a bit sweaty, and the way he mentioned feeling “off.” My mind immediately started running through possible diagnoses, especially since I’d seen a few patients today with odd, overlapping symptoms that didn’t fit any textbook illness. Should I just recommend a restaurant and keep things light, or should I probe further, risking overstepping our casual relationship? The expectations of being a supportive acquaintance clashed with my responsibility as a doctor to notice and act on potential health issues. I stood there, torn, unsure which role should guide my next words.
